description: Uncertain. Attested since the nineteenth century. Compare niggle, fiddle.

entries.meaning: (rare) A long-handled fork for mixing or digging.
examples: A heap of it is then placed upon an inclined platform, under a small fall of water, and repeatedly stirred with a piggle and shovel  […]

verbs.description: piggle (third-person singular simple present piggles, present participle piggling, simple past and past participle piggled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dig or uproot; to scrape.
examples: I took my revenge on th' round-house, for I piggled all th' plaster off o' the walls that I could  […]
Then all nature was presently converted into an object for microscopic study, so that everything, whether near or far, must be piggled at and made clear to the utmost limit of human power.

entries.meaning: To cause to worry, to make uncomfortable; niggle.
examples: BUDD. Get up yourself, and shut up, too! You have piggled me enough, you old smooty-snoot!
But of what value is all that piggling, niggling, — you call the little thing piggling, niggling?
